com.googlecode.transloader.clone
Interface CloningStrategy

All Known Implementing Classes:
ReflectionCloningStrategy, SerializationCloningStrategy
public interface CloningStrategy

The API by which an object can be cloned using a different ClassLoader than that/those which loaded the Classes it references. It can be used directly or serves as the strategy interface for customising the behaviour of ObjectWrappers.

Author:
Jeremy Wales

Field Summary
static CloningStrategy MAXIMAL
          The implementation which clones every Object in the given object graph.
static CloningStrategy MINIMAL
          The implementation which clones as little as possible to make the given object graph use Classes that are the same as those that would be loaded through the given ClassLoader.
 
Method Summary
 Object cloneObjectUsingClassLoader(Object original, ClassLoader targetClassLoader)
          Clones the given object using the given ClassLoader.
 

Field Detail

MINIMAL

static final CloningStrategy MINIMAL
The implementation which clones as little as possible to make the given object graph use Classes that are the same as those that would be loaded through the given ClassLoader. This is the most efficient implementation to use simply for the purpose of making sure the returned object graph is perfectly compatible with all other objects referencing Classes loaded through the given ClassLoader. It is also the implementation that is most likely to succeed in cloning any given object graph because by attempting to clone as few objects as possible it is less likely to attempt to clone an object that cannot be cloned (e.g. a non-Serializable with final fields in a pre-Java-5 JVM).

However, the fact that it only clones what is necessary to make the object graph compatible with the given ClassLoader means that usually not all of the objects in the graph will be cloned. This means that, depending on the Classes in the object graph and which of these is the same if loaded through the given ClassLoader, it is possible that a top level object is not cloned but objects it references through fields are cloned. This effectively means that the existing object graph can be altered rather than a new, purely seperate object graph being created. This may not be what you want if you want to continue using the given object in its original context. In which case, use MAXIMAL.

See Also:
ReflectionCloningStrategy, MinimalCloningDecisionStrategy

MAXIMAL

static final CloningStrategy MAXIMAL
The implementation which clones every Object in the given object graph. The given object graph is not altered in any way and a completely new copy of the object graph referencing only Classes loaded through the given ClassLoader is returned. Only primitives, which are not Objects, are not cloned because they cannot be, as there is no concept of different references to the same primitive value in Java. Similiar in behaviour to SerializationCloningStrategy except that it can clone more object graphs because it does not rely on all referenced objects being Serializable and also performs much faster than serialization.

See Also:
ReflectionCloningStrategy, MaximalCloningDecisionStrategy
Method Detail

cloneObjectUsingClassLoader

Object cloneObjectUsingClassLoader(Object original,
                                   ClassLoader targetClassLoader)
                                   throws Exception
Clones the given object using the given ClassLoader.

Parameters:
original - the original object to be cloned
targetClassLoader - the ClassLoader by which to load Classes for clones
Returns:
the result of cloning the object graph
Throws:
Exception - can throw any Exception depending on the implementation
